awd_titl_txt: CIF21 DIBBS:  EI: VIFI:Virtual Information-Fabric Infrastructure (VIFI) for Data-Driven Decisions from Distributed Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Data discovery and data analytics often rely on the use of multiple data sources and data residing in distributed locations.  This project builds infrastructure that encourages data-driven discovery from distributed, fragmented datasets without requiring movement of massive amounts of data and without exposing sensitive raw datasets to end users.  The capability will be applied to a wide range of science topics: to the large sky surveys of astronomy, for which the collecting instruments are distributed nationally and internationally;  to classify Earth science satellite data; for the management of sickle-cell disease and antimicrobial resistance surveillance studies; and to integrate the highly distributed and fragmented data sources needed for multi-hazard mitigation and for sustainable and resilient human-building ecosystem research. The project outlines an ambitious and will enable interdisciplinary training in multiple universities and institutions, and contribute to the training of early career researchers

A Virtual Information-Fabric Infrastructure (VIFI) is created, allowing scientists to search, access, manipulate, and evaluate fragmented, distributed data in the information 'fabric' (the infrastructure to facilitate data sharing) without directly accessing or moving large amounts of data.  The system addresses the challenges of coordinating loosely federated infrastructure, distributed data management, security and privacy.  The architecture combines a set of loosely coupled components representing some proven capabilities with several emerging components. The VIFI infrastructure includes a novel orchestration layer for on-site analytics and hybrid-infrastructure (GPU, CPU) management, a dynamic secure container-based infrastructure which enables online adaptive analytics from unshareable data at distributed locations, and enhanced data and code management tools.  The layer also provides search, access and query based on improvements using persistent identifiers and automated semantic descriptions (or metadata) of raw data using semantic data mining techniques.  By integrating several NSF-funded components into a coherent whole, VIFI allows researchers to search, access, manipulate and evaluate data elements without requiring detailed familiarity with the data infrastructure itself.  The system contributes to and expands the sets of resources serving diverse communities, and is extensible to additional communities.  The project contains a substantial outreach effort, including training of early career scientists.

por.por_cntn:
The Virtual Information-Fabric Infrastructure (VIFI) for Data-Driven Decisions from Distributed Data presents new foundational and transformative infrastructure solutions for data-driven discovery from distributed and fragmented data without moving massive data across the network or without needing to expose raw datasets directly to data users. VIFI was developed jointly by the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, the California Institute of Technology, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Louisiana State University, Carnegie Mellon University, Florida State University, Lawrence Berkeley National Labs, Cleveland State University, the University of North Texas, Nova Southeastern University, North Carolina A&T State University, and Utah State University.

VIFI facilitates automated methods for data-driven insights to broader communities. VIFI empowers data owners, independent of their disciplines, to share their data and without data migration or directly exposing raw data. VIFI empowers data users to search, analyze, manipulate, and evaluate fragmented, distributed data within a virtual information fabric without direct access to or movement of large amounts of data. As such, VIFI enables analyses that are otherwise impossible, infeasible, or impractical. VIFI provides support for the full lifecycle of inquiry and data-driven discovery – from search, to query, to access, to analysis – without necessitating a high-end infrastructure for data movement or exposing sensitive data. To enable such support VIFI integrates: remote storage; distributed orchestration and hybrid infrastructure management; distributed data management; publishing; and, transparent access to resources. Thus, VIFI removes barriers between utilizing, developing, and remixing interfaces to data through a generalized, discipline-agnostic approach, enabling disciplines to explore questions that otherwise are impossible or infeasible to explore. VIFI demonstrates its capabilities within multiple science and engineering domains, including the Earth Science, Astronomy, and Sustainable Human-Building Ecosystems (SHBE) research communities.

For the aforementioned research communities, VIFI enabled automated classification and access to archived unannotated data, virtual federation of data collections to enable analyses across distributed data, and distributed testbeds to compare observed and simulated climate data at very high spatial resolution without moving massive amounts of data. In addition, VIFI enabled data and model sharing en masse, but without massive data transfers, facilitated analysis of proprietary data by others via derived data products, enabled analyses across unlike datasets through Domain Adaptation (DA) and Co-Training for Domain Adaptation (CODA), and, provided sweeping access to data for citizen-science and crowd sourcing. VIFI supported analysis over distributed, fragmented data from multidisciplinary, convergent research communities. For example, for the SHBE community, VIFI provided accessibility to relevant building and human behavior data, presented data-sharing pathways to previously un-sharable data, enabled data federation across the numerous participating disciplines of an inherently interdisciplinary field, and supported emerging applications of combined theoretical and testbed analyses to enable integrated sustainability and resiliency analyses.

Most prior work involving data sharing and distributed analytics includes high-speed network solutions, cloud-based approaches to host repositories, analytic tools and infrastructure that can analyze data moved to the algorithms, and computational infrastructures. Some prior projects focused on data sharing, while others focused on providing computing resources. In contrast, VIFI does not require the physical movement of data to a common location for analyses. Rather, it provides an infrastructure framework for analytics at and across distributed data sources. VIFI reduces costs while opening up new opportunities for data-driven inquiry by bringing the analytics to data hosting locations. VIFI enables aggregate analyses across a large number of distributed datasets. VIFI was developed using only open-source components. VIFI was evaluated and validated on innovative analytic workflows defined by Astronomy, Earth Science, and SHBE research teams.
